comment:
Peaty and smoky nose, with fresh undertones of citrus, blackberries and apples.
Peat and dark chocolate taste, with again those blackberry flavors. Full, rich and smooth
The finish is fantastic and long, with tobacco, chocolate, and dark oak notes.

After coming down off the highs of two rich Armangnacs this on first taste was disappointing however adding water really opened it up. As SH said vanilla, coconut, butter and more. It really is a lovely dram on the palate and lingers long on the side of the tounge. Now a couple of caveats. It says it's the peatiest dram...hmm that I just do not get. I suspect it's a case of measuring the peat levels of the barley then distilling it in a number of ways which miminise the end result. Although as PBM mentioned a while back there comes a point your palate really just doesn't notice additional pbm levels (I just noticed two acronyms with two separate meanings!).

I think where this one falls short a bit for me is i'm not a fan of the more lighter acidic peat type drams I prefer the rich full bodied Lagavullin 16 or Laphroaig 10 / Lore approach. The aftertaste is less than the mid taste. It does carry with a nice warming glow but nothing spectacular. Still if you are a fan of this peat style I can see why you would rate it so highly it is excellently blanced and executed on the mid palate.

I'd rate this 3rd after the Black Art 4 1990 and Octomore 10 yr Dialogos. 4.25 - 4.5.
Sweet, fruity on the nose. Rich caramel on the palate.
DAMN. Smoky as hell, but neither bitter nor unpleasant. Responds beautifully to a dash of water and lingers, long after, with the warmth of a fire.
most peated scotch f the world. like drinking an ashtray!
Have loved every edition of Octomore, and this one is no different. Perfect balance of peat, with a drop of water to open it up.

I never thought I'd be a fan of a strongly peated whisky.  I remember my first time I had a lightly peated Caol Ila, and I almost had to spit it out.  How my tastes have grown to a broader palette.   I really like this one...big sweet smoke on the nose, sort of like being around a campfire roasting marshmallows.  The taste is incredible---citrusy-smoky-sweet.  Did you ever grill  lemons over mesquite charcoal, and then use those lemons to make lemonade?  That's what this taste like.   The finish is smooth with a waft of delicate smoke.  The only reason I gave it '4' instead of '5' stars...the price.  Quite pricey for a 5  year old.
On a side note...FINALLY...Lance Mayhew and I agree on something!!!  Till now, I generally ran opposite of his recommendations...hmmm...maybe to go back and give the other drams a 2nd chance?
If you enjoy a peaty & smoky scotch then this one is for us! Wow! Great flavors with a long lasting smoky finish ... An excellent scotch whisky!

If you're looking for a great whisky that you can drink every night while you relax in front of the TV this is NOT that dram.  Complex, bold, vibrant, demanding; the descriptors could go on and on... This is an amazing whisky! Absolutely over the top, yet understated; rich and full, yet delicate; hot and spicy, yet sweet and floral.  It's an oxymoron in a bottle...like nothing I've ever had before.  Pop the cork and a campfire fills the room (my wife smelled this from 18 feet away the instant I opened it). Getting past the smoke and peat, you can find a bit of old leather (think horse saddle or well-used carpenter's belt) and a field of fresh-cut hay.  The palate opens unsurprisingly with smoke and sweet peat, but doesn't dominate and hide everything. Citrus, hard nuts, vanilla, stone fruit and rose petals are there for the tasting, all wrapped in an underlying honey-like sweetness.  The finish is all smoke and takes forever, leaving an ashy taste in your mouth for more than an hour.  Add water, and things get even more interesting!  The nose stays the same, but the smoke is amplified and dominates the palate entry before a showcase of sweet peat, pears, vanilla and clover honey cascade across your tongue.  The finish is slightly drying with a pleasant numbness preceding the campfire that leaves your mouth dry and wishing for more.  I've never had a whisky get more smokey with water, but this does.  Eminently drinkable straight, but almost a different dram when cut to about 50% ABV.  I know it's expensive, and I know it's hard to find, but if you love Scotch, and you like Islay malts, you simply must try to find a glass of this...

Jodium (Sam zegt tweedehands kleding winkel)
Zwaar op de tong
Niet turf,
Overheersende volle smaak
Perfect om een avond tafelen mee af te sluiten

Too much voor mij, eenzijdige smaak
first tried in Rosemary Beach at The Pearl bar

Wonderful bouquet of smoke/peat without the medicinal iodine taste found in many (okay most) Islay malts. There's also a surprising and most welcomed sweetness to it. The 57% is unannounced, so enjoy this single-malt at home.
With Weej at Mandalay. Very peaty but very enjoyable

It's big but don't be scared by the PPMs. It's so big your pallet doesn't know what to do with it. I feel like I've had Ardbegs that are bigger. It's like when you touch dry ice and it feels hot. Believe it or not,  nice and smooth for the age. Great whisky!
Stunning. Smooth and smoky, but with enough bite to remind you that you're drinking a strong whiskey.
Strong peat but surprisingly smooth and balanced.  94/100.

Really strange whisky. I would not have guessed the 167 ppm and what's up with the vanilla? Really? Not as smokey and it was surprisingly  sweet. A little water brought in some more salty and meaty notes. I liked this more than the Coryvreken.

Very light straw color. Briny and salty on the nose. Undertone of earthiness. Initial taste of smokey earthiness. A light oiliness. Bitter on the back of the tongue, probably due to the high alcohol content. Definitely benefits from a splash of water.

Had it neat. Surprisingly smooth.  On the nose I immediately sensed chocolate and not that smoky to be honest.  Once in my mouth it tingles my tongue. I find it fruity and sweet on the palette.

Paid $105 @ Willow Park Reg $139

Wow. Its as if your literally eating a peat bog. I would describe this whisky as a child that just learned how to curse and just got caught cursing in front of a parent. The parent turns to another parent and says "that kids got quite the mouth on them." A whisky that feels like heartburn in the best kind of way.
Would like 4.5.  Very delicious.  Healthy level of peat and heat.

Color: more bronze and gold
Nasal: chocolate cover cherries with the cream filling, evergreen
Uncut: smoke-peet, smoke
Cut: full body creamy smoke, touch of iodine
Had a quick taste of this at the Baltimore Whiskey Festival. It was much more balanced than I expected with vanilla and a wonderful mouth feel balancing the well-stated peat.

Although this is undoubtedly a "peat bomb," with a staggering 167 phenol parts per million, what's so surprising about this lovely dram is the complexity on hand.  On the nose you get, sure, ash and smoke and peat, but there are also floral notes to be found and a pleasing honey and vanilla sweetness.  I also detect a lick of sea salt as well.  That dance between the warming smoke and the delicate sweetness is repeated on the palate before being overtaken by an impressive smokiness that never becomes overbearing.  Despite the high ppms and the 57% ABV, this is a very easy drinking spirit.  It's like someone tossed a honeycomb onto a peat fire.  Delicious.

This is a special combo of huge peat, and fruity sweetness that is just totally unexpectedly balanced. I just can't explain how good this is. The nose is crisp and salty and has no hint of what is about to hit you ... spicy , rich , sweet huge on smoke and peat bomb - Wow !
Smooth. Smoky peat, creme brûlée, seaweed, iodine, vanilla, raisin, touch of spice, cinnamon.
A killer, pretty hard to drink a lot of it.
Very peaty, as if I drank an Australian bush fire, smooth though. More of a tasting whisky than a drinking whisky. More of a novelty.
A hint of baking spice on the nose and a full, warm body that pulls through to an earthy, light finish.
Very smoky with hint of vanilla finish
Very peated and very expensive taste.
Seriously wow! Super peated, caramelic and sweet. Complex

6.1 is probably the introductory Octomore.  It is the cheapest (I purchased my bottle for $136) and most easily found.  Caviar analogy: if Islay whiskies are fish eggs, Octomores are from the sturgeon, and the Octomore x.3 is the Beluga sturgeon; if you only have the funds to splurge on one bottle, you may as well go for the 6.3 or the 7.3, which are in the $200-250 range.  Octomore 6.1 is solid, but a mere gateway to an expensive and heavenly range.  NOSE: Sweetness, smoke, and brine in perfect balance!  It is glued together by a rich buttery oiliness.  This is what Corryvreckan wants to be.  It literally smells like caviar.  Campfire embers and gasoline are in the background.  This is a tamed 167 phenols.  The numbers are a gimmick, and are probably measured right after malting.  It does not reflect the smokiness of the distillate.  TASTE: The peat explodes.  Bruichladdich believes in terroir, and it shows in their Octomore.  Strong heathery, earthy flavors.  There is smokiness, but also there is a taste of unsmoked soil.  A good youthful profile of fresh barley and lemon zest emerges and lingers into a long finish.  A long chestwarming feeling and aftertaste of hydrocarbons make you feel like you can light candles with your breath.  WITH WATER: Nose gets sweeter and fruitier.  Caviar and grape jam.  Palate loses the explosion of peat, but you get more subtlety and iodine on the arrival, with a drying earthy ash taking over after a few seconds.  VERDICT: Octomore publicity is based on extreme phenol levels and an “I-dare-you” variety of word-of-mouth.  It is actually as sophisticated and luxurious as an Islay whisky gets, with so much more to offer than a proverbial peat-punch to the face.  MARK: 94/100.

WOW, I think I just grew chest hair! Really good stuff here, with notes of honey and lemon zest on the nose. The palate is herbaceous and slightly sweet, with an obviously generous dose of smoke. On the finish, there's a nice touch of bitterness akin to dark chocolate that lasts for minutes on end, coupled with wood spices that needs water to tame down. Great stuff.
Everything I’ve ever wanted in a whiskey — burnt ham, old cheese, cherries, grass, mud

Marcliffe 17.3.2018
Lys gulaktig på farge. Beskjeden bouqet. Ren, klar på smak, meget kraftig. Masse smaker, litt honning, godt røket. Meget god ettersmak.
4.5/5
warm. like sliding next to a fire on the beach. smokey with hints of salt. a sweet finish that wraps the body with warmth.
Probably the finest peated single malt I have ever tasted. There is doubt the peat is there but it is so full of cream, caramel and light dried fruits. Super smooth for a 5 Year Cask Strength whisky.

N - sea salt / brine 
T - peat obviously, there is a fruity and sweet note but I can’t tell what it is 
F -  smoke, heat / pepper

For the love of peat this thing was tasty. I generally love preaty whiskies and this lives up to the hype.
The cask strength hits me more than the peat, to be honest. Perfectly drinkable
So peaty. lives up to the reputation.
Insanely smooth. Sweet, subtle caramel; vanilla; and lots of extremely well-integrated peat.
The smoke is very mellow for the rating.
Got a bit of a bite, super peaty which lingers in the mouth
This has to be the heaviest peated whiskey I have ever had. While super intense smoke, also incredible smooth.  Found it to be briny, but there was a subtle sweetness to it as well.

Bottle killed on 4/29/2019

Bruichladdich Distillery OB
Octomore Edition 06.1 Scottish Barley
5 years old
57% ABV
Bottled 2013
Price: 174 USD

I finished my SECOND bottle of this gorgeous peat monster, and that is the only Octomore that I can make that claim about.  Part of that is because this is fairly available where I am, and prone to being found on sale, and part of that is because this is irresistibly delicious.

This whisky is a mammoth in the La Brae tar pit.  Oily hydrocarbon-covered tusks right up your ass; so beautifully balanced with fully mature bourbon influence.  This will rival a 20 year old single malt in complexity, but you need some water to bring this down to about 46-50% ABV to smooth out the sharp edges.  I swear, soot fleetingly precipitates out of solution when water drops hit this 18k golden liquid.

Behind the sooty and tarry smoke, there are exquisite notes of vanilla, pineapple, coconut, butter, and sea salt.  And, yes, there is caviar.  The finish is long and dynamic.  Occasionally, I even get pickled vegetables and MSG towards the end.  If you have a fondness for peat, this will be a luxurious experience; a quintessential Islay hug.

Rating (Price not factored): 94 / 100
Purchase Satisfaction (Price factored): 4.5 / 5

Expected to feel the peat more. Nose is excellent, fruity and really enjoyable. The sweetness surprised me, wasnt expecting that. Rich flavor, strong, curiously felt the peat more after adding few drop of water. Liked it, a bit strong for my taste but will definitely explore more.
so much peat. tastes warmer than it is. a lot to take in
Very smokey but not enought bite to compete with Ardbeg.

trouble in mecca.

does not taste haram
Best with one straw (~1.5 inch) of water.  More gets super oily
Absolutely fantastic. Nose is filled to the brim with all kinds of different notes ranging from smoked meat and leather to Orange blossom and tar. Expressive notes of Peat on the palate. Wonderful.
A bit smoky, but great finish
Smoky but not overpowering. Ridiculously smooth. Sweet Parrish start.  Good islay finish.
Wow. Peat. One of the peatiest scotches in the world. And you can tell. Not much there in complexity honestly. I just absolutely love it.
super smokey. lots of booze. very good.
This is my first octomore experience and all I can say is... In Avengers EndGame when the Ancient One knocks Bruce Banner out of the hulk? This is the closest I'll ever be to that.

On the nose: kerosene, malt, and sharp vegetal peat. Distinct burning sensation with hints of cheese. The taste begins just as intense but rewards you with a feast of malt, oil, and smoke that leaves you with one of the best aftertastes you'll ever experience.
Awesome. Peaty leathery smoke on the nose and finish, fruity citrusy body reminiscent of apples and light lemon.
Fruity sweet with a heavily smoked finish.
My favorite peated whisky so far. Exactly like the description; super smoky but balanced by sweetness. Low petrol taste which is nice. Need to buy a bottle.
